>Another purpose for using JUnit is to create tests
>first and then write code.  For those that take this
>approach to development, they would probably want a
>test for each method.

I'm sorry to be blunt, but absolutely not.

In TFP, the goal is to test every feature -- that is, every bit of behavior 
you care about. Implementation details are unimportant and, in fact, testing 
them on their own often impedes refactoring. Since tests are meant to 
provide the "safety net" during refactoring, they should try not to get in 
the way of refactoring, if they can avoid it.

If you have one feature that uses four or five private methods behind a 
single public method, then it's best simply to test the public method. If 
you find a bug in there, then that may be a clue about your design: perhaps 
what you perceive as an implementation detail is something bigger that 
should be in its own class. At that point, the method becomes public and 
voila, you can test it. (Or package-level, if you prefer that route and 
place your tests in the same package as the production code.)

"A test for each method" is a bad thing. "Tests for each feature or service" 
is a Good Thing.
